newsitem.title: CHINA: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end up, spots down.
newsitem.headline: Shanghai T-bill repo rates end up, spots down.

text.p: Contracts on the treasury bill repurchase market in Shanghai closed mostly up on Thursday, with short-term money demand increasing due to new domestic A share issues and listings and the rise of the A market, traders said.
The annual rate for the most active seven-day rose to 12.00 percent from 10.00 percent on Wednesday.
Turnover more than doubled to 12.91 million lots from 5.9 million. One lot is 1,000 yuan face value of treasury bills.
Nanjing Panda Electronics issued A shares in Shanghai today, one new firm listed today and a second will list tomorrow. Shanghai's A share index rose by 1.47 percent today.
Traders believe the rates will move around current levels in the next few days.
Contracts on the T-bill spot market in Shanghai ended mostly down in slow trading on Thursday on weak sentiment, traders said. The market has been on a downtrend in the past few weeks.
The most active 10-year bond that matures in June 2006 fell slightly to 122.40 yuan from 122.70 yuan. Combined volume of the eight-contract market fell to 886,566 lots from 1.20 million.
Traders said the market would remain weak in the short term. -- Shanghai newsroom (86-21) 6279-7004
